name: Virginia Hamill
biography: One of the first American women in the field of industrial and product design, Virginia Hamill (1898–1980) called herself a “decorative art consultant.”  She was primarily known as an exhibition organizer and designer, retail merchandiser, product stylist, and interior designer and educator. The versatile Hamill’s clients included RCA Victor (for which she designed radio cases), the Libbey Glass Company (display and showroom design), Cannon Mills (color consultant), International Silver Company (product styling), and retailers R.H. Macy and Co., and Lord & Taylor (merchandising, expositions, public programs). She taught interior design at Parsons School of Design, and was considered influential in her use of department store exhibitions to introduce European modernist design to mainstream American consumers.
